title: 108_s1983
content: The Act may be cited as the "SNIPER Act of 2003" and enforces compliance with record-keeping requirements. The "SNIPER Act of 2003" amends Section 923 of title 18, United States Code, regarding inspections and ammunition sales. Inspections are increased to 4 times a year for violators, and ammunition sales regulations are modified. The "SNIPER Act of 2003" amends Section 923 of title 18, United States Code, to increase inspections to 4 times a year for violators and modify ammunition sales regulations. This includes amending Section 923(g)(1)(A) to include ammunition sales and penalty enhancements in Section 924(a)(1). SEC. 3. ENFORCEMENT ACTIONS AGAINST VIOLATORS OF FEDERAL FIREARMS LAWS. Section 924 of title 18, United States Code, allows for the revocation, suspension, or fines for licensed importers, manufacturers, dealers, or collectors who violate firearm laws. Section 923(g) authorizes the Attorney General to issue warning letters and maintain records for violators identified during inspections. The Attorney General can revoke, suspend, or impose fines on licensed firearm dealers for violations. The Director of Industry Operations must make a final decision within 120 days of mailing a notice to the licensee. The Brady Handgun Violence Prevention Act defines a term in section 103(j)(1). Judicial stays of enforcement actions under title 18, United States Code, require a court order to postpone the effective date. Enforcement actions are not dependent upon criminal convictions. SEC. 4 amends Section 922(b)(3) of title 18, US Code. SEC. 5 introduces ballistics testing of firearms. The TRACE Act aims to increase public safety by assisting law enforcement in solving gun-related crimes through ballistics technology. It requires ballistics testing of all new firearms for sale and those in custody of Federal agencies to aid in identifying firearms used in crimes. Additionally, it adds ballistics testing to existing firearms enforcement programs. The TRACE Act mandates ballistics testing of new firearms and those in Federal custody to aid in solving gun-related crimes. Licensed manufacturers or importers must test fire firearms and prepare ballistics images as specified by the Attorney General. The TRACE Act requires licensed manufacturers or importers to test fire firearms, prepare ballistics images, and store fired bullets and cartridge casings as specified by the Attorney General. The Attorney General will assist in compliance by acquiring necessary equipment for manufacturers and importers. The Attorney General is responsible for establishing a database of ballistics images, coordinating with law enforcement agencies, and taking necessary steps to make ballistics testing effective. The Attorney General is required to establish a database for ballistics records accessible to law enforcement agencies, conduct mandatory ballistics testing of firearms, and submit annual reports on the implementation of this section to Congress. The Attorney General must establish a database for ballistics records accessible to law enforcement agencies, conduct mandatory ballistics testing of firearms, and submit annual reports to Congress. $20,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2005 through 2008 for equipment installation and testing sites. The Attorney General must establish a database for ballistics records, conduct mandatory ballistics testing of firearms, and submit annual reports to Congress. $20,000,000 is authorized for equipment installation and testing sites. Additionally, funding is allocated for casing recovery equipment, ballistics testing sites, personnel salaries, and related research and evaluation. The effective date of the amendment depends on the certification of the ballistics system's readiness for mandatory testing of new firearms. The amendment to Section 923 of title 18, United States Code, will take effect 2 years after the enactment of the Act. Ballistics information from individual guns cannot be used for prosecution unless there is a reasonable belief that a crime has been committed and the information would assist in the investigation. SEC. 6. ADDITIONAL FUNDING FOR THE BUREAU OF ALCOHOL, TOBACCO, FIREARMS, AND EXPLOSIVES. The Attorney General will establish gun crime task forces in each field division of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives to investigate and regulate licensees and unlicensed dealers suspected of violating federal laws. $10,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year 2005 for these task forces. For fiscal years 2005-2008, $10,000,000 is allocated annually for subsection (a) provisions. Additionally, $25,000,000 is authorized each year for Industry Operations to hire more inspectors, regulators, and employees in the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives.
